Oculus Quest's 1st Top-Notch Sports Game

Don't let the "simple" graphics fool you. This 2 Minute Drill(2MD) football game and motion throwing simulator is the 1st unforgettable sports experience in VR. You'd be a fool to overlook it.
2MD Football Unleashed at its core is an arcade football simulation that puts you in the role of QB as you lead your team on a game winning drive with 2 minutes left on the clock. There are 7 teams to defeat, with the difficulty and the amount of points you need to score increasing as you stack up wins.
There are 8 teams to choose from, each with their own home stadium and marching song(although I recommend playing with music off). Your team colors are fully customizable with sliders for Red, Green,and Blue.
Upon loading into your locker room, you are presented with a whiteboard, where you can design up to 8 plays that are mapped to your left and right controllers. Each play can be mirrored by a double press of your play selection, essentially giving you 16 plays to choose from.
There is a practice field you can use to practice your throwing skills. Here you can adjust your Throw Power and Release Point, so that you can play the game with the most natural throwing motion possible(I recommend spending a bit of time fine tuning these settings).The experience can feel quite special when your throwing motion meshes with the action in your headset, and the game can feel funky if you don't set it to your comforts.
All in all, this game is a must purchase experience for any fan of sports games. While this game doesn't have the team management aspects or deep franchise/season modes of sports sims on consoles, it houses what could be the best emulation of what it feels like to play football.
I grew up playing sports and always regretted giving up football after my freshman year of high school. Madden has always been fun, and the 1st person mode in NFL 2k5 was the closest a game ever got to replicating that on-field feeling. Until now.
From the Friday Night Lights feel of the Truant's home field to the shower of lights in the Pixel Dome, each team's stadium is awe-inspiring(along with the touchdown celebrations designed for each stadium). It feels like youre there on the biggest stage possible. Throwing passes around the field to receivers that are running routes you drew up. It's wild. Even the weight of the headset on your head begins to feel like you're wearing a football helmet, complete with a face mask framing your vision.
Along with being untethered to a gaming rig, allowing you to take snaps and drop back, it creates one of the most immersive and interesting VR experiences I have had thus far. It's amazing to me that a team of 3 or 4 people pulled off a project like this.
I love that when you finally beat that final team, you get to wear a championship ring on your finger from then on. I just wish that the rings would stack up on the rest of your fingers when you win more championships! It would be so cool being blinged out with rings while tossing hotstreak TDs to that open receiver downfield. Hopefully that's something thats possible in an update!
I loved the multiplayer experience thats possible on PSVR, but totally understand how tough it would be to make possible on the Quest. I currently play my friend by live streaming a campaign in a Facebook group and then comparing scores after we each play. Maybe it would be possible to have an NCAA style OT situation where teams take turns on the 20 yrd line and have to score in 4 downs, and you watch the other team play from the sidelines when its their turn to try, possibly even trying from further and further away with each successful series? In truth, I dont know what's possible. A fan can only dream.
Having those 8 teams to choose from is great, but I would certainly pay for a dlc pack of new teams and stadiums. Hopefully that's something that can come in the future!
If you've read this far, I hope you make the smart choice and give this game a shot. At the very least, you can say you played the og game that brought true virtual football when everyone is marvelling at whatever nuts stuff Madden 2030 is dishing out in the future.

Well, I finally managed to beat the game, so I figured I'd update my review and share my experience.

First of all, to the game's credit, until I beat all 7 rounds, this is the only game I played for several weeks (obviously I don't play as frequently as others, but that was still a nice size playtime).

Basically if you like American football and want to try out being a QB this game is a must have. The immersion of scanning the defensive formation, trying to see where coverage is going to find an open man, all while ensuring you dont get sacked (on later levels anyway) is a whole lot of fun.

There are all kinds of situations that you always imagine yourself in if you've watched football as a fan - getting sacked on your blind side while trying to find a receiver, converting a 3rd and long, seeing lots of green in front of you and scrambling for a first down, threading the ball in a tight window you weren't sure was going to make it, hitting a hail mary, taking the easy "check down," hitting a receiver in stride, scoring the winning touchdown as time expires, etc etc.

If you ever played ncaa games like madden or ncaa, this is nothing like that. Even with the dummy graphics the immersion is great. Somehow that 1st person qb experience makes you feel the pressure of each play in a way traditional football games could never do.

Now that I've touted the games merit, I'll breakdown reasons it is a bummer at times
1. The difficulty increase of each level is not linear at all. The first 4 levels are incredibly easy. Then suddenly at lv5 you have to score twice as much in the 2min period to win. Also defense starts intercepting and sacking way more.
2. The entire game is 7 rounds of 2min drill. If you score a touchdown in 2 min you win (2 TDs needed for last 3 rounds). There is no defense, no 4 quarters, no seasons, etc.
3. Although it is possible to hand off a ball for a run in the game, it is not a viable option. You can only pass or scramble if you want to gain yards.
4. For the achievements section (trophy case), there is one trophy I won't even try to earn because it goes against the games limitations. There is a trophy awarded for 10 consecutive completions. In reality this is nearly impossible since you will likely score and win the round before ever completing 10 passes.

Now for a tips section with my advice after hours and hours of playing:
1. Most important part of the game - go to the practice field and adjust your release height until the throwing feels natural. Before when I did not do this, I kept throwing the ball in the dirt, getting frustrated, and I couldn't throw it far at all. This should be required to start the game imo but it is not.
2. Google receiver routes if you don't know the basics. I didn't know anything and the game doesn't explain it. After I studied some I was able to make effective plays.
3. Learn the difference between lofty passes and line drives. On the later levels if you loft balls high in the air its probably a guaranteed interception.
4. On later levels you have to watch the linemen and linebackers as soon as you snap to see if you are about to be sacked. Running away from them can buy you some time. You may also want to leave a TE to block instead of putting everyone on routes
5. Snapping the ball early before the defense is set seemed to help gain an advantage at times.
6. Watch the corners and safeties and see what direction they move. If they move away from where your WR is going you can anticipate where he will be open and throw to that spot
7. When you complete 3 passes in a row you get "hot streak" which means you can't be intercepted, and your guys move faster.
8. Skip the carnival game between rounds, it just wears out your arm and you can't play the actual game as long.

Bug report: when i beat round 7 the message "2nd place" still displayed, even though I got the Champion trophy.
